fields.title: Pride and Prejudice
fields.author: Jane Austen
fields.summary:
In a world ruled by wealth, reputation, and rigid expectations, Elizabeth Bennet dares to think for herself. Sharp-tongued, observant, and unafraid to challenge authority, she navigates a society where marriage is less about love and more about survival. When the wealthy and aloof Mr. Darcy enters her life, their first encounters are marked by wounded pride, misunderstandings, and clashing values.

As families interfere, secrets surface, and emotions deepen, both Elizabeth and Darcy are forced to confront uncomfortable truths about themselves. What begins as mutual dislike slowly transforms into self-awareness, growth, and a love built on respect rather than status. Witty, romantic, and deeply human, Pride and Prejudice explores how love matures when pride softens and judgment gives way to understanding.
fields.content:
It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession of a good fortune, must be in want of a wife.

However little known the feelings or views of such a man may be on his first entering a neighbourhood, this truth is so well fixed in the minds of the surrounding families, that he is considered the rightful property of some one or other of their daughters.

"My dear Mr. Bennet," said his lady to him one day, "have you heard that Netherfield Park is let at last?"

Mr. Bennet replied that he had not.

"But it is," returned she; "for Mrs. Long has just been here, and she told me all about it."

Mr. Bennet made no answer.

"Do you not want to know who has taken it?" cried his wife impatiently.

"You want to tell me, and I have no objection to hearing it."

This was invitation enough.

"Why, my dear, you must know, Mrs. Long says that Netherfield is taken by a young man of large fortune from the north of England; that he came down on Monday in a chaise and four to see the place, and was so much delighted with it, that he agreed with Mr. Morris immediately; that he is to take possession before Michaelmas, and some of his servants are to be in the house by the end of next week."

"What is his name?"

"Bingley."

"Is he married or single?"

"Oh! Single, my dear, to be sure! A single man of large fortune; four or five thousand a year. What a fine thing for our girls!"

"How so? How can it affect them?"

"My dear Mr. Bennet," replied his wife, "how can you be so tiresome! You must know that I am thinking of his marrying one of them."

"Is that his design in settling here?"

"Design! Nonsense, how can you talk so! But it is very likely that he may fall in love with one of them, and therefore you must visit him as soon as he comes."

"I see no occasion for that. You and the girls may go, or you may send them by themselves, which perhaps will be still better, for as you are as handsome as any of them, Mr. Bingley may like you the best of the party."

"My dear, you flatter me. I certainly have had my share of beauty, but I do not pretend to be anything extraordinary now. When a woman has five grown-up daughters, she ought to give over thinking of her own beauty."

"In such cases, a woman has not often much beauty to think of."

"But, my dear, you must indeed go and see Mr. Bingley when he comes into the neighbourhood."

"It is more than I engage for, I assure you."

"But consider your daughters. Only think what an establishment it would be for one of them. Sir William and Lady Lucas are determined to go, merely on that account, for in general, you know, they visit no newcomers. Indeed you must go, for it will be impossible for us to visit him if you do not."

"You are over-scrupulous, surely. I dare say Mr. Bingley will be very glad to see you; and I will send a few lines by you to assure him of my hearty consent to his marrying whichever he chooses of the girls; though I must throw in a good word for my little Lizzy."

"I desire you will do no such thing. Lizzy is not a bit better than the others; and I am sure she is not half so handsome as Jane, nor half so good-humoured as Lydia. But you are always giving her the preference."

"They have none of them much to recommend them," replied he; "they are all silly and ignorant like other girls; but Lizzy has something more of quickness than her sisters."

"Mr. Bennet, how can you abuse your own children in such a way? You take delight in vexing me. You have no compassion for my poor nerves."

"You mistake me, my dear. I have a high respect for your nerves. They are my old friends. I have heard you mention them with consideration these last twenty years at least."

"Ah, you do not know what I suffer."

"But I hope you will get over it, and live to see many young men of four thousand a year come into the neighbourhood."

"It will be no use to us, if twenty such should come, since you will not visit them."

"Depend upon it, my dear, that when there are twenty, I will visit them all."

Mr. Bennet was so odd a mixture of quick parts, sarcastic humour, reserve, and caprice, that the experience of three-and-twenty years had been insufficient to make his wife understand his character. Her mind was less difficult to develop. She was a woman of mean understanding, little information, and uncertain temper. When she was discontented, she fancied herself nervous. The business of her life was to get her daughters married; its solace was visiting and news.

fields.title: Jane Eyre
fields.author: Charlotte Brontë
fields.summary:
Jane Eyre's life begins in loneliness and injustice, shaped by cruelty, loss, and emotional neglect. Yet beneath her quiet exterior lies a fierce sense of dignity and moral strength. As she grows, Jane refuses to accept a life defined by oppression or dependency.

Her position as governess at Thornfield Hall introduces her to Mr. Rochester—intense, secretive, and burdened by a past he cannot escape. Drawn together by intellect and emotion, their connection deepens amid shadows and unanswered questions. As love collides with hidden truths and societal limits, Jane must choose between surrendering her principles or standing alone. This powerful novel is a journey of self-respect, resilience, and a woman's right to love without losing herself.

fields.title: Wuthering Heights
fields.author: Emily Brontë
fields.summary:
Set against the untamed Yorkshire moors, Wuthering Heights tells a story of love that is as wild as it is destructive. Heathcliff, an orphan driven by abandonment and rage, forms an unbreakable bond with Catherine Earnshaw—a bond that transcends reason, time, and even death.

Their passion is fierce, obsessive, and unforgiving, leaving devastation in its wake. As jealousy, pride, and revenge consume generations, love becomes a force capable of both creation and ruin. Dark, haunting, and emotionally intense, this novel explores the consequences of loving without restraint—and the scars left behind when love turns cruel.

fields.title: Gone with the Wind
fields.author: Margaret Mitchell
fields.summary:
Scarlett O'Hara is beautiful, willful, and determined to survive—no matter the cost. As the American Civil War tears through her world, privilege fades, society collapses, and survival becomes a daily battle. Scarlett clings to love, ambition, and land with equal desperation, refusing to surrender even when everything familiar is stripped away.

Caught between obsession, pride, and resilience, her journey is filled with heartbreak, passion, and moral conflict. Sweeping in scope and emotion, Gone with the Wind is a story of endurance, flawed humanity, and the relentless will to live—even when love is uncertain and tomorrow is not promised.

fields.title: Outlander
fields.author: Diana Gabaldon
fields.summary:
Claire Randall never expected to lose her century. One moment she's a nurse in post-war England, the next she's thrown into the dangerous, politically charged world of 18th-century Scotland. Armed with modern knowledge but trapped by history, Claire must navigate clan rivalries, suspicion, and violence.

As danger closes in, she forms a powerful bond with a Highland warrior whose loyalty and passion challenge everything she believes about love and fate. Torn between two lives and two eras, Claire faces impossible choices. Rich in history, adventure, and emotion, Outlander is a sweeping romance where love defies time itself.

fields.title: The Notebook
fields.author: Nicholas Sparks
fields.summary:
Their love begins simply—young, reckless, and full of promise. But life, distance, and expectations soon pull Noah and Allie apart. Years later, their story is pieced together through memory, sacrifice, and an unbreakable emotional bond.

As time tests devotion and life leaves its marks, their love proves enduring in ways neither could have imagined. Tender and deeply moving, The Notebook is a tribute to lasting love, reminding readers that some connections are written not just in the heart—but in fate.

fields.title: P.S. I Love You
fields.author: Cecelia Ahern
fields.summary:
Holly's world ends when the love of her life dies—but his voice refuses to disappear. Through letters written before his death, she is gently guided through grief, fear, and the challenge of learning how to live again.

Each message pushes her to rediscover joy, courage, and independence while honoring a love that never truly leaves. Emotional yet hopeful, P.S. I Love You is a comforting story about loss, healing, and the quiet strength it takes to begin again.

fields.title: Sense and Sensibility
fields.author: Jane Austen
fields.summary:
Sisters Elinor and Marianne Dashwood experience love from opposite ends of the emotional spectrum. Elinor believes in restraint, duty, and quiet endurance, while Marianne follows her heart with reckless abandon. Both face heartbreak, disappointment, and the harsh judgment of society.

As circumstances test their beliefs, the sisters learn that neither reason nor emotion alone is enough. Graceful, insightful, and emotionally layered, Sense and Sensibility explores maturity, resilience, and the many forms love can take.

fields.title: The Fault in Our Stars
fields.author: John Green
fields.summary:
Hazel Grace Lancaster has learned to live cautiously—until Augustus Waters enters her life with humor, charm, and fearless honesty. Together, they explore love, pain, and the meaning of leaving a mark on the world.

Their connection is raw, funny, and devastatingly real. With sharp dialogue and emotional depth, The Fault in Our Stars captures the beauty of loving fully, even when life offers no guarantees.

fields.title: Anna Karenina
fields.author: Leo Tolstoy
fields.summary:
Anna Karenina appears to have everything—status, beauty, and security—but her heart longs for something more. When she dares to follow her desires, she challenges society's rigid moral code, triggering consequences that ripple far beyond herself.

Intertwined with other lives shaped by duty and longing, this novel is a profound exploration of love, betrayal, family, and identity. Deeply psychological and emotionally complex, Anna Karenina reveals how passion can both illuminate and destroy.

fields.title: The Rosie Project
fields.author: Graeme Simsion
fields.summary:
Don Tillman is brilliant, methodical, and utterly convinced that love can be solved like a scientific equation. Social cues confuse him, emotions overwhelm him, and romance feels like a puzzle with too many missing pieces. Determined to take control, Don designs a highly structured questionnaire to find the perfect partner.

Then Rosie walks into his life—chaotic, emotional, unpredictable, and everything his system rejects. As their unlikely connection deepens, Don begins to question whether love is something to be calculated or felt. Funny, touching, and refreshingly honest, The Rosie Project celebrates difference, growth, and the beautiful messiness of human connection.

fields.title: Rebecca
fields.author: Daphne du Maurier
fields.summary:
When a shy young woman marries the wealthy widower Maxim de Winter, she is swept into a life of privilege at his grand estate, Manderley. But the shadow of his first wife, Rebecca, looms everywhere—in whispered conversations, lingering memories, and the chilling presence of the house itself.

As insecurity turns to obsession, the new Mrs. de Winter begins to question what really happened to Rebecca and what secrets her husband is hiding. Dark, atmospheric, and filled with psychological tension, Rebecca is a haunting exploration of identity, jealousy, and the danger of living in someone else's shadow.

fields.title: The Thorn Birds
fields.author: Colleen McCullough
fields.summary:
Spanning generations, The Thorn Birds follows the Cleary family as they build a life in the harsh yet beautiful Australian outback. At the center is Meggie Cleary, whose life is shaped by forbidden love, sacrifice, and longing that never truly fades.

Bound by faith, family, and fate, the characters grapple with choices that echo across decades. Sweeping, emotional, and deeply romantic, this epic novel explores love that is both transcendent and tragic, asking how much one should sacrifice for the heart's deepest desire.

fields.title: The Time Traveler’s Wife
fields.author: Audrey Niffenegger
fields.summary:
Henry DeTamble lives with a condition that forces him to jump unpredictably through time. Clare Abshire lives a life rooted in waiting—loving a man who is sometimes present and sometimes gone without warning.

Their relationship unfolds out of order, filled with stolen moments, longing, and resilience. As time pulls them apart and brings them together again, their love is tested in ways few relationships could survive. Tender, unconventional, and emotionally powerful, The Time Traveler's Wife is a meditation on fate, patience, and enduring love.

fields.title: Me Before You
fields.author: Jojo Moyes
fields.summary:
Louisa Clark lives a small, predictable life—until she becomes caretaker to Will Traynor, a once-adventurous man now trapped by circumstances that have stolen his independence. Bitter, intelligent, and emotionally closed off, Will resists connection, while Louisa refuses to give up on him.

As their relationship evolves, both are forced to confront difficult truths about freedom, love, and what it means to truly live. Heartbreaking yet hopeful, Me Before You is a deeply emotional story about choice, compassion, and the courage to care.

fields.title: One Day
fields.author: David Nicholls
fields.summary:
Emma and Dexter meet once—and that single day becomes the anchor point for their intertwined lives. Each year, the story revisits them on the same date, revealing how love, ambition, regret, and timing shape their connection.

As their paths diverge and collide, moments of closeness are missed, and opportunities slip away. Honest, bittersweet, and painfully real, One Day captures the fragility of human connection and the quiet heartbreak of 'what if.'

fields.title: Eleanor & Park
fields.author: Rainbow Rowell
fields.summary:
Eleanor stands out everywhere she goes—and not in ways that feel safe. Park is quiet, observant, and unsure of where he belongs. When they begin sharing bus rides, a slow, awkward, and deeply sincere connection forms between them.

Their first love is intense, fragile, and shaped by fear, music, and stolen moments. As life outside their bond becomes increasingly complicated, they must learn what love can and cannot protect. Eleanor & Park is a raw, heartfelt story about identity, vulnerability, and the power of being seen.

fields.title: The Hating Game
fields.author: Sally Thorne
fields.summary:
Lucy and Joshua share an office—and a mutual obsession with making each other miserable. Their daily battles of sarcasm, competition, and carefully calculated annoyance blur the line between rivalry and attraction.

As playful hostility turns into undeniable chemistry, both must confront their own insecurities and fears about vulnerability. Sharp, witty, and sizzling with tension, The Hating Game proves that sometimes the strongest feelings grow where you least expect them.

fields.title: Happy Place
fields.author: Emily Henry
fields.summary:
Harriet and Wyn were the perfect couple—until they weren't. Now, forced to pretend everything is fine during a group vacation, they must face the reality of what went wrong and what still lingers between them.

Set against laughter, shared memories, and emotional honesty, Happy Place explores love, identity, and the painful beauty of second chances. Warm, reflective, and deeply relatable, this novel captures the quiet heartbreak of growing apart—and the hope of finding your way back.

fields.title: The Kiss Quotient
fields.author: Helen Hoang
fields.summary:
Stella Lane thrives in numbers and routines but struggles with intimacy. Determined to change that, she hires Michael, a professional escort, to teach her the rules of dating and physical connection.

What begins as a transaction quickly becomes something deeper, challenging both to confront vulnerability, self-worth, and emotional risk. Sensual yet tender, The Kiss Quotient is a celebration of love that defies expectations and embraces imperfection.
